label: Acre Geoglyphs
column6: large-scale earthworks located in Brazil’s western Amazon
column7: created by pre-colonial Indigenous societies possibly as early as 1000 BCE. Believed to serve ceremonial or social purposes
column8: over 400 of these geometric structures have been discovered.

label: Boha geoglyphs
column6: discovered in 2014 in India’s Thar Desert
column8: intricate line formations spanning up to 48 km
column9: possibly created using plow tools. Believed to be around 150 years old
column10: their purpose and origin remain debated
column11: with some experts suggesting they are natural formations.

label: Geoglyphs of Umbarle
column6: estimated to be around 10000 years old
column7: have been discovered in Maharashtra's Ratnagiri district
column8: with seven in Umbarle village and one in Borkhat village. These rock carvings depict human and animal figures and are part of the Konkan region's extensive petroglyph heritage.

label: Steppe Geoglyphs
column5: The Steppe Geoglyphs of Kazakhstan are over 260 massive earthworks—shapes like crosses
column7: and swastikas—discovered in the Turgai region
column8: some dating back as far as 8000 BCE. Their origin and purpose remain mysterious
column9: with theories linking them to ancient Neolithic societies or later cultures.

label: Amazon Basin Geoglyph (one of many)
column5: LiDAR scans of the Amazon Basin have uncovered vast geoglyphs—precise geometric earthworks like squares
column9: indicating advanced knowledge of geometry and astronomy. These monumental structures
column11: suggest the presence of a sophisticated pre-Columbian civilization.

label: Works of Old Men (one of many)
column5: The Works of the Old Men are vast geoglyph-like stone formations—wheels
column7: and keyholes—scattered across the Arabian Desert
column8: visible only from the air and dating back to at least 7000 BCE. Their purposes remain debated
column9: ranging from animal traps and settlements to possible astronomical or ritual functions.
